The product shall be available during normal business hours. As long as the user has access to the client PC, the system will be available 99% of the time during the first six months of operation.
The application shall have a downtime of at most 10 minutes per year.
The system shall achieve 95% uptime.
The product shall be available for use 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.
Out of 1000 accesses to the system, the system is available 999 times.
The system shall be available for use between the hours of 8 am and 6 pm.

The RFS system should be available 24/7, especially during the budgeting period. The RFS system shall be available 90% of the time all year, and 98% during the budgeting period. 2% of the time, the system will become available within 1 hour of the time that the situation is reported.
Design the system for high availability with minimal downtime.
Redundancy: Implement redundancy for all critical components.
Failover Mechanisms: Implement automatic failover mechanisms to ensure continuity.
Disaster Recovery: Develop a comprehensive disaster recovery plan.
Geo-Redundancy: Use geo-redundancy to ensure availability across different geographic locations.
Uptime SLAs: Define and adhere to strict uptime Service Level Agreements (SLAs).
Continuous Monitoring: Implement continuous monitoring to detect and address issues promptly.
Backup and Restore: Regularly backup data and ensure quick restoration.
Fault Tolerance: Design the system to tolerate and recover from faults.
Maintenance Windows: Schedule maintenance windows to minimize impact on availability.
Load Balancers: Use load balancers to distribute traffic and prevent overloads.
Health Checks: Implement regular health checks for system components.
Rolling Updates: Use rolling updates to deploy changes without downtime.
Service Resilience: Ensure services are resilient and can recover quickly from failures.
Scalable Infrastructure: Use scalable infrastructure to handle peak loads.
Data Integrity: Ensure data integrity during failures and recovery.
High Availability Clusters: Implement high availability clusters for critical services.
Zero Downtime Deployments: Aim for zero downtime during deployments.
Incident Response Plan: Develop an incident response plan to address availability issues.
System Alerts: Set up alerts for any availability issues.
Service Contracts: Establish service contracts with providers to ensure high availability.
Dependency Management: Manage dependencies to prevent single points of failure.
Regular Testing: Regularly test the high availability setup.
Capacity Overprovisioning: Overprovision capacity to handle unexpected spikes.
Decentralized Services: Use decentralized services to avoid central points of failure.
Version Control: Maintain version control to quickly rollback in case of failures.
Cloud Services: Utilize cloud services that offer high availability guarantees.
Performance Isolation: Isolate performance-critical components to ensure availability.
Service-Level Monitoring: Monitor service levels to ensure compliance with availability requirements.
Business Continuity Planning: Develop a business continuity plan to maintain operations during major disruptions.
Automate recovery procedures to minimize downtime.
Use redundant DNS services for high availability.
Deploy high availability network appliances.
Decouple services to prevent cascading failures.
Overprovision capacity to handle unexpected spikes.
Use automated configuration management tools.
Ensure redundant internet connections for external services.
Use snapshot backups for quick recovery.
Implement auto-restart for critical services.
Replicate data across multiple geographic locations.
Set up real-time alerts for failover events.
. Use a multi-cloud strategy for better availability.
Implement proactive error handling to prevent downtime.
Regularly review and improve availability strategies.
Automate failover testing to verify the systems ability to switch to backup systems.
Ensure real-time replication of critical data across multiple locations.
Continuously monitor system latency to identify and resolve potential performance issues.
Implement load shedding mechanisms to manage traffic spikes without affecting system availability.
Use distributed databases to enhance availability and data redundancy.
Use service level monitoring tools to ensure compliance with availability metrics.
Apply load balancing techniques across multiple servers to distribute traffic evenly.
Develop and document a redundancy plan for all critical system components.
Implement tools to monitor the health of both hardware and software components continuously.
Perform regular availability audits to identify and address potential weaknesses.
Automate failback procedures to return to the primary system after a failover event.
Use multiple geographic data centers to provide redundancy and geographic failover.
Ensure the system can handle partial failures without impacting overall availability.
Implement remote monitoring capabilities to manage and address issues from different locations.
Conduct regular data backups to ensure quick restoration in case of system failures.
Equip critical components with redundant power supplies to prevent outages.
Keep spare hardware components available for quick replacement of failed parts.
Implement network redundancy to prevent single points of failure in network connectivity.
Set up automatic reboots for critical services to recover from unexpected failures.
Continuously monitor the availability of third-party services integrated with the system.
Create dashboards to visualize the status of system components and services.
Establish and document recovery time objectives (RTO) and recovery point objectives (RPO).
Deploy high-availability storage solutions to ensure data is always accessible.
Use cloud providers that offer high availability and auto-scaling features.
Use middleware solutions designed for high availability to manage system communication.
Create disaster recovery plans that address various failure scenarios.
Regularly conduct failover drills to test the effectiveness of the failover process.
Use both hot (active) and cold (standby) systems to ensure continuous availability.
Set up real-time alerts for immediate notification of system issues and downtime.
Use a microservices architecture to isolate and manage service availability more effectively.
Utilize continuous data protection technologies to ensure minimal data loss.
Develop procedures for managing incidents to minimize downtime.
Monitor environmental conditions (e.g., temperature, humidity) in data centers to prevent hardware failures.
Ensure the system can scale horizontally to handle increased loads without affecting availability.
Implement active-active configurations where multiple systems handle traffic simultaneously.
Regularly perform load testing to ensure the system can handle peak loads.
Use automated configuration management to maintain consistency and reduce manual errors.
Ensure redundant internet connections to maintain connectivity during outages.
Use external monitoring services to provide an independent check on system availability.
Implement snapshot-based recovery mechanisms for fast data restoration.
Track system throughput to detect and resolve performance bottlenecks.
Deploy high-availability firewalls to protect against network failures.
Design applications to isolate faults to prevent cascading failures.
Analyze system logs regularly to identify and address potential issues.
Use real-time data validation to ensure data integrity during system operations.
Implement end-user notifications for planned maintenance and unexpected downtimes.
Follow industry standards for high availability to ensure best practices.
Implement self-healing mechanisms to automatically detect and fix issues.
Cross-train staff and provide redundancy for key personnel to manage system availability effectively.
The system shall allow users to easily switch between different sections or modules.
The product shall include a "getting started" guide for first-time users.
The product must support Internet Explorer 5.5 and above.
The product must support Mozilla Firefox 1.0 and above.
The product shall interface with the Choice Parts System. This provides the feed of recycled parts data.
The product shall run on the existing hardware for all environments.
The product shall adhere to the corporate Architecture guidelines.
For estimators, the product shall be able to be operated in a repair facility during dirty and noisy conditions.
The product shall interface with the ChoiceParts system once per day at approximately 1.
The maintenance of the product will fall within the established corporate maintenance windows.
The product shall be supported using the corporate support center.
Product installations and upgrades shall be handled by the middleware technology team within established launch time frames.

The product must work with most database management systems (DBMS) on the market, whether the DBMS is colocated with the product on the same machine or is located on a different machine on the computer network.
The product will function alongside server software on any operating system where the Java runtime can be installed.

The product will require collaboration with a database management system (DBMS). The DBMS may be located on the same machine as the product or on a separate machine residing on the same computer network.
The product must make use of web/application server technology. Open source examples include Apache web server, Tomcat, and the JBoss application server.
A database management system such as Oracle, DB2, MySql, or HSQL will need to be integrated with the product.
The product shall be used in office environments.

The product must be able to interface with any HTML browser. The product shall transmit data between the user and the product without problems. The product shall display HTML properly in 80% of all HTML browsers tested (minimum is to test 8 browsers).
The product must be able to interface with various database management systems. The product shall communicate successfully with the database management system on 100% of all transactions.
The product must be able to interface with various email servers. The product shall be able to send email.
The product shall be available for distribution via the Internet as a binary or ZIP file.
The product shall be available for distribution as a packaged CD.
The product will be available for licensing as a one-server, two-five servers, or five-or-more servers license.
The System shall utilize currently owned computer equipment.
The System shall be able to automatically backup business data and restore them on demand.
The System shall not require additional third-party licenses resulting in royalty fees.
All aspects of the website shall be accessed by a web browser over the Internet.
The same hardware supporting the current website will be used to support the new system.
We must be able to interface with the following browsers.
Website must interface with the CyberSource API to process credit card transactions.
Website must be fully operational with MSN TV2.
Movies shall be encoded and streamed via Windows Media Player 9.0.
Movies shall be encoded for 56k and 256k streams.
The product shall be able to be installed in the specified environment within 1 working day.
The product shall be platform independent. The product shall enable access to any type of development environment and platform.
The product shall interface CSR and Datastream. The product shall exchange messages between CSR and EAM on a real-time basis without any direct interfaces between two systems.
The WCS system shall be run in a Windows environment. The WCS shall be accessed by users through the Internet on an IBM computer running a Windows 2000 or above operating system.

The Brio portion of the WCS system must be able to export files in spreadsheet form (Microsoft Excel and Lotus 1-2-3 formats). Brio will provide buttons in the user interface that produce/export reports in .xls or .123 file formats.
The application shall run on a web application server.
The Disputes application shall be available 24x7x365 with the exception of the following scheduled maintenance windows: Monday, Saturday 3.

The Disputes application shall interface with the Statement Database. The Statement Database provides the transaction details to the Disputes System. All transaction details must be obtained from the Statement Database.
A primary database will be used to store cached data for active users.
The system shall be able to operate within a business office environment typical of the Nursing Department at DePaul University.
The system shall be used within the specifications defined by the computers used by the Program Administrators/Nursing Staff Members.
A secondary database will be used to store historical statistics and data.
The system shall operate within the Windows XP Professional operating system.
The system shall interface with CampusConnects central server.
The system shall interface with the faculty central server.
The system shall interface with the student master server.
We must be able to interface with any HTML browser.
